console.special: Best selling video game colsole of all time, to date. Nearly 2000 games released, and launched some of the best games ever made. I lost more hours of my life then I can count to this game console. Time well spent.

Never was there a gaming system that was more fun than the N64. Four players could make and break friendships through either playing Super Smash Brothers or 007 Golden Eye, among others. The bonus was that you were right next to your friends playing, so you could duke it out immediately to assert physical and digital dominance after winning. The good old days.

This console arrived at a special time in my life, when I was old enough to recognize that I was a total nerd, yet young enough not to realize that being uncool was actually cool. The SNES made being young and socially awkward seem less daunting; the games were outstanding and original, and you could easily get wrapped up in them for over 50 hours if you dared. Such fond memories.

As an "old man" now, I feel the need to share my experiences with the original NES system while sitting in a rocking chair and sipping a Jolt Cola. This is where legends in the gaming community began. Mario transformed into Super Mario, Link saved Zelda for the first time, and we discovered what a Megaman was all about. Plus, who could forget shooting digital birds with a laser gun? Absolutely legendary.
In 1989, when I was young, Santa gave me one of these. I believe this single-handedly started my love for video games.

The console had a ridiculous lineup of games, including several exclusives like Metal Gear, Uncharted, and Infamous. However, the lack of backwards compatibility frustrated many loyal gamers who had PS2s, but eventually, most people got over it. Not me, BOOOOO Sony.

Nintendo made a new type of gaming system that works as both a home console and a handheld device. Now, you can play whenever and wherever you want. Good move by Nintendo. I spent about three months playing "Breath of the Wild". Worth it.

Sony's breakout video game console, the PlayStation, marked their shift from making Walkman's to entering the gaming business. The iconic loading screen sound of the PlayStation is permanently burned into my brain. For me, the real reason to own one was the Final Fantasy franchise, but there were also titles like Gran Turismo and Twisted Metal.

This is the console that served as the foundation for the video industry. Atari 2600 was undeniably a phenomenon during its rise, heralding the advent of a new entertainment medium. If you haven't played Adventure by Warren Robinett, at least watch a video of it, that was a cool game for its time.

Microsoft's breakout video game system was a success, unlike the Zune. Ewww Zune. Years before Microsoft became an evil organization and required all users to have a Microsoft account to use Windows, it revolutionized the gaming industry with two major innovations: Xbox Live and Halo. Online gaming and freaking Halo.

Once again Microsoft continues to keep the dream alive with its enhanced version of the Xbox. And once again, online play and Halo are the two pillars that supported their system. And it worked: millions of Mountain Dew-addicted gamers screaming into Doritos-crusted headsets, making fun of your gaming skills and your mama online, creating the first truly toxic online gaming experience for casual gamers. Glorious.

There were brief moments when the SEGA Genesis surpassed Nintendo. SEGA had several advantages when it launched, one of which was Sonic the Hedgehog. Additionally, SEGA embraced more mature content, allowing games like Mortal Kombat on the Genesis to feature blood and gore, while the SNES refrained from this due to strict content policies at the time. This gave SEGA a momentary edge over Nintendo. However, that changed with the release of iconic titles such as Final Fantasy VI, Chrono Trigger, Gradius III, Contra III, Mega Man X, and Secret of Mana, which caused many players to shift their focus back to Nintendo. Sad Sonic noises.

This was the power equivalent of the SNES at the time, but in handheld form. This was the perfect GameBoy for gamers to get their Pok√©mon addiction established before completely overdosing on it when the 3DS came out. Pika pika.

The Nintendo DS was successful because it introduced touchscreen controls and enabled wireless online gaming, reaching a wide audience. This helped create a casual gaming market that attracted many non-gamers and set a standard for touchscreen controls in future portable gaming devices. The DS also brought more female gamers into the market. In 2006, Nintendo reported that 44% of DS owners were female, and many owners of the game Nintendogs were also female. Absolute win.

OMG... Another PlayStation. Sony gave you the privilege of re-buying all your PS2 and PS3 games on the "new" PS4, yay! Additionally, many excellent games received remakes, with Shadow of the Colossus and God of War notable examples. Red Dead Redemption was the real reason to own one, in my opinion.

The system prioritized a simple user interface over high-definition and surround sound. The biggest change was not just in the games, but in how we played them. The aim was to create something easy for anyone to use, with a new input method; the hope was to reach a broader audience and bring more people into gaming. There were record televison sales after its release due to adults and children alike throwing their WiiMote into their televison screens by accident. Use that wrist strap.

It was a foldable hand-held gaming system that was simply fun. While it didn't boast high-end graphics or hardware, it provided an interactive gaming experience with two screens and a stylus. Soo many hours lost at work with this bad boy.

The SEGA Dreamcast was the first console in the sixth generation of video game systems, which included the PlayStation 2, GameCube, and Xbox. It used a GD-ROM... not CD or DVD, GD. A CD can hold 700mb and a DVD can hold 4.7gb, but GD... it held 1.2gb. Weird. It launched in 1998, over two years before the PS2 and three years before the GameCube and Xbox. Three years later and it was a dead console.. its a GD-ROM shame.

SNK was a well-known company that made arcade games and published games for the NES in the late 1980s. In 1990, the company decided to use its arcade skills to create games for home use. King of Fighters and Metal Slug 3 are some of their best games.

Its a Cube. It played little DVDs. It had the worst controller ever made. Is it special? Yes. A wooden knife is special too, but it can't cut a damn thing. Special is not always good. Epic fail in my book. At least it had a handle... like you were going to take it anywhere, lol.
